RGM Reimagined!

At the Consumer Pricing & Revenue Growth Management Summit Europe, our team led a hands-on workshop on Interconnected RGM, co-hosted by Claudius Roth from Imperial Brands. Together, we explored what it takes to operationalize RGM at scale, from governance frameworks that hold across regions to data-driven flexibility that adapts to market realities.

The session brought together RGM leaders and practitioners who shared real examples of how pricing, promotions, and portfolio decisions evolve when insight flows seamlessly across teams. Key discussions included:
‚û°Ô∏è Practical frameworks for scaling RGM capabilities.
‚û°Ô∏è Success stories that show what works and what doesn‚Äôt in global execution.
‚û°Ô∏è A case study that unpacked the tension between global consistency and local agility.

Zahid Hossain, AVP ‚Äì Global Business at Tiger Analytics, also joined a panel on Vendor‚ÄìRetailer collaboration, emphasizing how shared insights and structured communication are essential to move from negotiation to partnership.

It was great to connect with leaders shaping the future of RGM through innovation, collaboration, and practical execution. Thanks to everyone who joined and contributed.

üüßüü®üü© A great career in AI is built like a game of Tetris. Every project adds a new piece to your stack: Some test your optimization skills, while others stretch your design thinking. Each one shapes how you approach the next move. The pace quickens, the board fills up, but with every fit, you see the pattern forming. 

At Tiger Analytics, it‚Äôs the variety across projects and domains that helps us level up ‚Äì optimizing demand forecasts for global retailers with probabilistic ML models, fine-tuning recommender systems for edge latency, designing LLM agents for claims processing in insurance, generating synthetic data to test fraud models in banking, and building retrieval-augmented pipelines for faster insight generation in manufacturing. Add in peer-led learning, open design reviews, and deep dives across data science, MLOps, and platform engineering, and you get the perfect alignment between skill, curiosity, and growth.

üé• Hear from our AI leader, Sudalai Rajkumar - SRK, on how we‚Äôre building for CertAInty, one block and one breakthrough at a time.

How can one of the world‚Äôs largest dairy cooperatives push the boundaries of what‚Äôs possible with AI?

We explored this question with FrieslandCampina‚Äôs CDAO, Jo√´lle van der Bijl, and her leadership team during their visit to our Bengaluru office. 

A big thank-you to Jo√´lle, Debaparna, and Mayank for sharing your insights on how emerging technologies can make organizations more agile and customer-focused in a VUCA world.

The day was packed with interactive sessions and live demos of AI solutions that create impact across key enterprise functions, featuring:
‚û°Ô∏è AgentFlow, a codified, open-source factory for building and managing AI agents, powering Agentic AI use cases across key processes.
‚û°Ô∏è Stripes AI, a platform transforming sustain operations with summarization, resolution automation, and centralized monitoring.
‚û°Ô∏è Sense AI, focused on explainable and trustworthy AI-led insights.

The day captured what we value most at Tiger Analytics: open dialogue, co-creation, and a shared belief in using AI responsibly to create real value. We look forward to deepening this collaboration and turning ideas we exchanged into action.

We are thrilled to be a part of the Snowflake Intelligence Launch Partner ecosystem, helping enterprises operationalize reasoning within their data environment.

Snowflake Intelligence connects natural language understanding, retrieval, and governed execution directly inside the Snowflake Data Cloud. For instance, a customer analytics team can ask ‚ÄúWhy did last night‚Äôs customer churn spike in Region South?‚Äù and receive a transparent answer that connects renewal data, communication logs, and service metrics within the same secure environment.

This is just one of the many possibilities. From diagnosing data pipeline failures to optimizing operations, Snowflake Intelligence is extending the scope of what AI can reason and act on, securely and in context.

Together with Snowflake, we are enabling Enterprise Intelligence Agents that move beyond insights to decisions, with trust and explainability built in.

Read the full blog to see how this shift is shaping the next phase of enterprise AI: https://lnkd.in/dHYuhHK7

Sifting through manuals during a critical operation isn't just slow, it's a risk.

For a fleet as large as OSM Thome's, ensuring every team member could apply the correct safety protocol instantly was a complex data challenge. We partnered with them and built a generative AI assistant, ASK OSMTHOME, that integrates Microsoft Azure OpenAI and Cognitive Search to unify all their safety knowledge into one conversational interface.

Now, teams get the right safety information in seconds. It‚Äôs a 98.8% gain in decision efficiency, but more importantly, it's greater confidence and safety for everyone on board.

üöÄ How to think like a FAANG product lead?
Or more importantly, should you?

According to research from Harvard, of the estimated 30,000 new products launched every year, only the ones that keep users at the center and evolve with feedback endure. This is at the heart of product thinking. 

Take our work with a global CPG brand, looking to optimize planogram audits. Instead of building yet another model, our data scientists used product thinking to design a modular, offline app powered by adaptable ML models that learned with every new SKU. The results: 85% faster audits, 90% accuracy and a system that keeps learning across 10+ markets.

Our Data and AI leader, Karthik Ragunathan, drills down on how exactly data scientists can fuse a product-thinking mindset to align solutions more closely to business objectives and bridge the project value gap. Read the four ways a product thinking approach helps create lasting AI solutions in hashtag#TigerPerspectives: https://lnkd.in/duiJS9CG

Domain ownership. Embedded governance. Automated policy enforcement.
 ‚Äã
These aren't just operational buzzwords. They make up the foundation of data systems that drive business outcomes.‚Äã

Across industries, we're seeing a shift towards federated domain models, where teams own their data products, governance is built into workflows and policies enforce themselves through automation. ‚Äã

At Ataccama FWRD on November 6, Sam Ramachandran, Chief Sales Officer at Tiger Analytics, and Larry Hunt, Field CDO, Ataccama, will explore this transformation. The session, Scaling Data as a Product: How Federated Domain Models Unlock Business Outcomes, will unpack how leading organizations are architecting data as a product: moving beyond centralized bottlenecks, distributing ownership where it matters, and building governance that scales without friction.‚Äã

Join us for this important conversation about making data ownership and governance part of everyday delivery.‚Äã

Mama Mia! M unlocks a new high-score in predictive analytics with InsightsPro

Say hello to M, an AI engineer navigating the complex world of dashboards, pipelines, and endless queries. Coins (insights) are scattered everywhere, power-ups (tools) boost her abilities, and every level brings new challenges to master. 

She wields her trusty InsightsPro, our Agentic AI solution, to help everyone from Operations Directors to CFOs and CMOs turn raw data into real-time, actionable insights with:

üéÆ Co-op agents for every challenge: SQL generation, charting, predictive modeling, RAG, web search, Python data modeling ‚Äî each agent is a teammate, handling tasks automatically while M focuses on designing higher-level strategies.

üéÆ Dynamic query power-ups: InsightsPro intelligently detects question types ‚Äî descriptive, comparative, predictive, and diagnostic ‚Äî then dynamically orchestrates the right agents to fetch, model, visualize, or summarize responses.

üéÆ Scaling levels: Cloud-agnostic and multi-LLM compatible, InsightsPro securely handles growing datasets and diverse analytical needs at scale, empowering teams across the business with insights.

For engineers like M, working with InsightsPro is like building the game while playing it. Every agent, every adaptive pipeline, every optimized insight is a move that levels up the system, empowers the team, and scores high in business impact.

Engineer Your Enterprise for AI, or Watch Others Rewrite the Rules.

The conversation around AI is shifting from isolated use cases to a more profound question: How can we fundamentally re-engineer the enterprise for the AI era? Incremental changes are no longer enough.
At Tiger Analytics, we believe true transformation requires a bold vision. At the upcoming Chicago CDAO Executive Summit, our team will share practical strategies for embedding AI into core operations, equipping attendees with actionable frameworks to inspire ambitious, organization-wide change.

We're focused on helping leaders:
üî∏ Move from Automation to Autonomy: It's not just about improving old workflows, but creating entirely new, intelligent, and autonomous ways of operating with Agentic AI.
üî∏ Build an AI-Native Foundation: We architect the resilient data ecosystems and robust governance frameworks that allow you to innovate safely and scale with confidence.
üî∏ Drive Strategic Transformation: We partner with you to identify and execute on opportunities where AI can redefine business models and create an enduring competitive advantage.

How do you optimize optimization?
We‚Äôve found that success with large-scale optimization hinges on modelling decisions and use-case-specific strategies.

Solver choice is a critical decision that shapes solution quality, speed, and scalability for data scientists, analytics engineers, and operations researchers.

In our latest white paper, we benchmark leading open-source solvers across real-world problems, and unpack how to:
üî∏ Align optimization problem structures with solver performance
üî∏ Map business challenges to the right algorithm-solver combinations
üî∏ Weigh practical trade-offs like convergence issues and ease of development.

Build scalable, reproducible pipelines for complex OR use cases
This guide shares practical insights for analytics and operations teams in supply chain, manufacturing, retail, and marketing to build real-time, resilient decision systems at scale.

The consensus is clear: To truly realize AI‚Äôs potential, we must move beyond siloed experiments and embed it into the DNA of decision-making, infrastructure, and leadership accountability.

That insight directly tied to the ROI question AI leaders brought to #MachineConUSA2025. The panel ‚ÄòCan AI ROI move from small wins to transformative profits or will it remain a mirage?‚Äô hosted by Asif Ghatala (Vice President & Business Unit Head, Tiger Analytics), shed more light on how we can bridge the gap between promising pilots and enterprise-wide impact.

What emerged from this discussion across healthcare, banking, and nutrition industries:

üî∏ The focus is shifting from simply finding AI use cases to prioritizing the ones that align closely with specific business goals
üî∏ Significant disruption opportunities exist even in highly regulated industries like banking and pediatric nutrition
üî∏The real hurdles that leave AI stuck at the experimentation phase: unclear KPIs and lack of integration with core business functions
üî∏ Implementing robust guardrails and governance systems is crucial for managing AI deployments at scale

Thanks to the panelists Rama Donepudi (SVP & Global CIO, Mead Johnson Nutrition), Manav Misra (Chief Data and Analytics Officer, Regions Bank), and Arys Nogueron (Campaign Director of Data Analytics, Reporting, & Governance at NYU Langone Health) for sharing their perspectives on leveraging AI in ways that create sustainable, long-term business value.

Where does bias hide in your test design, and can AI seek it before it plays out?

Even well-designed tests can run into trouble when faced with real-world complexity. In our work with analytics leaders across CPG and retail, we‚Äôre seeing AI refine experimentation, making tests cleaner, faster, and more reflective of live environments. Here‚Äôs how:

- Sampling grounded in actual customer behavior
- Control groups selected with timing, weather, and local footfall in mind
- Survey outreach optimized by likelihood to respond
- Multi-Armed Bandits adapting campaigns in-flight, not after the fact

Product thinking asks us to go further to connect the dots - recognizing users, finding patterns in problems and creating sustainable, replicable solutions. ‚úèÔ∏è Who will use this solution?

‚úèÔ∏è Does it drive lasting impact?

What does it take to make a GenAI system reliable at scale?

This was among the questions we explored at a panel discussion on ‚ÄòGenerative AI in Action: Enterprise Value Creation‚Äô in San Francisco on April 24. We partnered with Amazon Web Services (AWS) to dive into how nuanced GenAI strategies are driving measurable value. 

Key ideas that stood out:

- Generative AI is moving beyond theoretical applications, delivering tangible improvements in operational efficiency.

- Trust begins with data. Reliable outputs need a strong data strategy, built on rigorous quality control and proactive bias mitigation.

- Effective cost management hinges on strategic resource optimization along with well-defined outcomes for GenAI initiatives.

- To successfully scale AI pilots, businesses must focus on clear objectives, interdepartmental collaboration, and an iterative development process focused on demonstrable value. 

A big thank you to our panelists Kathleen L. D. Maley, Shubham Kulshrestha, and Jimmy Shah for sharing their insights and experience.

From empowering GenAI solutions to driving smarter decisions, data is the real MVP. 

Investing in data cleanliness can save companies millions and turn their data into a true strategic asset. Over thousands of projects across AI and analytics, we've developed a handy data quality framework that helps organizations: 

- Automate validation to catch errors early 
- Deduplicate intelligently 
- Standardize formats across systems

Adopting the right solution architecture is a critical factor in the success of your GenAI adoption. Not every use case requires training a foundation model from scratch √¢‚Ç¨‚Äù so how do data leaders determine the best fit?

Foundation √¢≈æ¬°√Ø¬∏_x008f_ Implementation - Key factors to consider:
- Solution type: An enterprise model API may be enough, while some use cases require fine-tuning open-source models or building custom solutions.
- Scalability & cost: Striking the right balance between customization, performance, and long-term viability.
- Risk management: Identifying potential risks at each stage and planning mitigation strategies.

How do work-life harmony, risk-taking, and imposter syndrome intersect? They're the common threads in our careers that test us, teach us, and push us to evolve.

As part of our Women√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢s Day celebrations this month, we hosted a panel on March 6, featuring Shreyas Narayan, Sunitha Gunasekaran, Aswathy Augus, and Sandeep Yeddu of the #TigerTribe, to bring a fresh perspective on how we approach these challenges.

Some takeaways:

√∞≈∏‚Äú_x008d_ Work-Life Harmony: The perfect balance is a myth. It√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢s all about finding a rhythm that works for you √¢‚Ç¨‚Äú one that is personal, context-driven, and evolves with time. Most importantly, don√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢t hesitate to ask for help, whether at home or work.

√∞≈∏‚Äú_x008d_ Risk-Taking: Every career move involves a trade-off between risk and regret. Early in our careers, we√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢re quick to take risks, but with time, appetites change. The key is calculating risks to protect what matters most, while still embracing opportunities for growth.

√∞≈∏‚Äú_x008d_ Imposter Syndrome: Everyone has those √¢‚Ç¨≈ìam I good enough?√¢‚Ç¨_x009d_ moments, but they don√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢t define us. Instead, we can turn them into opportunities for growth, learning, and building the confidence to push past self-doubt.

A huge thank you to our panelists for sharing your insights, tips, and personal stories. You reminded us that growth is not linear and while these challenges may be universal, our responses can be empowering.

At Infinity AI Day 2, the conversation took a powerful turn with AI for Her:

Leading with Purpose and Impact√¢‚Ç¨‚Äùa thought-provoking discussion on women in AI, data biases, and leadership. Moderated by Rashmi Tambe, Head of Digital Engineering at Tredence, the session brought together inspiring voices: Amruta Joshi (Google Cloud), Radhika Kannan (Intuit), and Smita Naveen (SAP).

The panel delved into the topic of bias in AI, examining how AI often reflects societal inequalities and why ensuring data quality is essential in every AI product. The speakers highlighted how traditional assumptions, such as leadership positions being dominated by one demographic, shape AI systems√¢‚Ç¨‚Äùand stressed the importance of including diverse perspectives to help reshape the AI landscape.

The conversation also addressed imposter syndrome, the reluctance women sometimes feel about pursuing careers in AI, and the empowering potential of low-code/no-code solutions in democratizing access to AI, making it more inclusive and accessible to all.

The message was clear: avoiding AI is a risk, and it√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢s time for more women to step forward, claim their expertise, and take the lead.

Building AI systems that work? It's not just about the technology. It's about governance at every layer.

Anuj Krishna, Cofounder and President, MathCo, breaks down the four critical governance questions organizations must answer:

Context: What does a central group own? How do business groups collaborate? How do feedback loops work?

Agents: How do you use existing agents? What needs to be built? Who owns what?

Orchestration: Who owns the framework? What kinds are needed? How do you apply it in business?

Interface: How do you design with users and personas in mind to make it real for them?

Each layer needs its own roadmap, governance model, and clear ownership. Or your AI system won't scale.

Watch the full breakdown from MachineCon 2025!

AIM

We recently brought together industry analysts and ecosystem partners at MathCo's Intelligence Hub in Bengaluru for a full-day event dedicated to exploring the state and future of enterprise AI transformation.
 
The reality is concerning: 88% of AI proof-of-concepts don't scale to enterprise-wide deployment, and only 25% of AI initiatives deliver expected ROI.
 
Companies invest heavily in experimentation, only to see initiatives remain isolated, fail to integrate with core processes, or struggle to demonstrate sustained value. Organizations lack a holistic framework that goes beyond individual use cases to address how AI integrates into core systems and decision-making workflows.

Charlie Madison began playing piano at six, encouraged by his parents, who hoped music might offer him a gentle focus and a new way to engage with his surroundings. ‚ÄúI was always told that rhythm and melody could help my senses connect,‚Äù he shares. Those early lessons were more than just notes‚Äîthey were a lifeline, a way to find comfort and confidence.

As Charlie grew, his relationship with the piano shifted. ‚ÄúAt night, after my family fell asleep, I‚Äôd play and sing songs from my favorite singer-songwriters,‚Äù he remembers. While he practiced classical pieces during the day, those nightly sessions were different. ‚ÄúExpressing myself musically felt like a secret, a safe space away from the pressures of being the nerdy kid in a sports-focused town.‚Äù The piano became his refuge, allowing him to find his own voice at a time when he felt like an outlier.

Charlie credits the piano with teaching him the value of patience and consistent effort. ‚ÄúRepetition, repetition, repetition‚Äîthat stuck with me, whether I‚Äôm practicing a piece or debugging a tough line of code. Artistry comes from showing up and working through the details.‚Äù He‚Äôs carried that mindset into his work at MathCo, taking pride in his focus and high standards, while also learning to embrace progress over perfection. ‚ÄúIn live performances, even if you make a mistake, you keep going. Most people won‚Äôt notice, and stopping just breaks the spell.‚Äù

For Charlie, music has always been about community‚Äîmemories of high school musicals, singing telegrams with friends, and small moments of validation, like the coffee shop owner who once wrote,‚Äú It‚Äôs clear you have a lot of poetry and music in you.‚Äù Those words still mean the world.

And for anyone looking to learn piano as an adult, Charlie offers this advice: ‚ÄúIf you want to play a few favorites, have fun! But if you want to learn truly, don‚Äôt skip the basics. They‚Äôre the key to unlocking everything music has to offer.‚Äù His journey is proof that patience and a love of the process can open doors‚Äîat the piano and beyond.

This World Photography Day, we celebrate how a simple passion can transform the way we see the world. For Chethan R, it began quietly in his backyard, photographing cats with a basic point-and-shoot camera.

But it was the visit to Kabini and the BRT Tiger Reserve that changed everything. "Something about watching animals in their natural habitat just clicked. I realized this wasn't just a hobby anymore‚Äîit was something deeper", he reminisces.

One of his most treasured captures features a leopardess at the Bhadra Tiger Reserve. "She had just woken up from a nap and was giving us all these poses. But when she yawned, that was pure magic." Such moments make the long waits worthwhile. "I've done over 100 safaris in tiger reserves and only seen tigers a couple of times. But when it happens, it's everything."

Wildlife photography outings are anything but predictable. "I've spent three hours in a forest without seeing a single bird or animal," he admits. "But that's part of the process. You do your research on animal behaviour and weather patterns, then you wait." He recalls waiting for a serpent eagle to retrieve its dropped kill, a Russell's viper snake. "We never got the shot, but the experience itself was incredible."

For those intimidated by wildlife photography, his advice is simple: "Start in your backyard. Photograph birds, squirrels, even insects. You don't need to fly to the Masai Mara right away", he quips.

The unpredictability that makes wildlife photography challenging is also what makes it beautiful. "Weather changes in an instant, animals don't perform on cue, and opportunities vanish in seconds. But sometimes that 'failed' outing leads to something even better", he reflects.

Chethan's journey proves that exceptional shots come from showing up consistently with patience and respect. Wildlife photography mirrors life itself‚Äîunpredictable, humbling, and ultimately rewarding.

For Venkatraman G S, Chief Financial Officer at MathCo, every step in his corporate journey has been thought through‚Äîtaking on challenges, driven by learning, discipline, and the belief that doing what's right for the organization matters more than convenience.

"If I had to sum up my journey in finance, it's been a fantastic one of constant learning, taking on roles that required me to acquire new skills, helping me set up and run multiple functions within Finance and Risk Management, building great teams, and growing as a finance professional."

"The journey evolved from doing Branch Accounting manually to being part of ERP rollouts, using technology to get real-time financial reports as a CFO for fast-growing companies. Working with inspiring leaders, observing them, and learning what makes them successful."

Taking on unfamiliar roles became a pattern, each pushing Venky to adapt and grow.

"As I stepped into roles I'd never done before‚Äîfront-ending client reviews, setting up business finance, or leading Enterprise Risk Management‚ÄîI realized growth doesn't come from having all the answers. It comes from asking the right questions, preparing well, and surrounding yourself with people you can learn from."

On what excites him most about MathCo, Venky says, "I see a younger, high-energy team solving high-growth problems, not just optimization ones. I'm excited to work with leadership to enable MathCo's continued fast-paced growth, both organic and inorganic."

"As we grow, it would be interesting to use some analytics and forecasting models we offer clients within finance. That's when it gets real: when belief in your product powers your own decisions."

When it comes to leading teams, he believes in clarity, fairness, and immediate feedback. "Be direct, be fair, and always offer feedback that helps people grow. Don't wait for reviews; give real-time input to build consistency and trust."

His advice to young finance professionals? Go beyond numbers.
"Knowing your function isn't enough. Understand your business, the customers you serve, the issues you help solve, and how your work fits the larger value chain. You're not 'just' doing reporting or payroll; you enable the business to succeed."

He sees the CFO role evolving fast, working closely with CEOs to enable growth and strategy, not just manage financials. "Technology is transforming how we work, and we must stay ahead. Finance teams must collaborate with engineers, product teams, and data scientists."

Looking ahead, Venky is energized by MathCo's momentum. "It's been a great start. We're solving good problems. I'm here to help scale the company, strengthen governance, and support leadership as we build the next phase of growth."

For Venky, one thing holds true: "Success isn't about getting everything right, it's about getting better every day and doing what's right for the organization, not what's convenient."

"What I value most is the support system, the mentors who guide you, the team that always has your back, and the belief that your work matters, no matter your designation."
 
Looking back, Isaac says, "MathCo gave me the foundation, exposure, and confidence to build a meaningful career in HR."

"I received my undergraduate degree in English from Penn State and thought my career would be in journalism or copywriting," says Catherine Laborde, Head of Human Resources and Operations at MathCo. "It wasn't until someone I worked for said, 'Have you considered working in HR? You could turn it on its head with your people skills, conversational style, and analytical brain.' That one comment opened a door I hadn't considered."

Catherine began her HR journey nearly 15 years ago at a large specialty food store in Philadelphia, supporting a bustling catering business and shipping warehouse.

"My office was directly above the store, which gave me an up-close view of the people's experience," they recall. "I dove into hiring, problem-solving, and day-to-day support. It was HR in its most hands-on, human form".

Since then, they've built a career that spans marketing and advertising, architecture and engineering, and tech sales, always with a people-first mindset. Prior to joining MathCo, they held leadership roles and worked in a global capacity, overseeing the US, Canada, EU, UK, and APAC region, which made MathCo's international team especially appealing.

"What drew me in was the opportunity to continue working on a global scale, but with a team that truly values empathy and intelligence in equal measure.

"Now at MathCo, I oversee Recruiting, Talent, Learning & Development, the overall people experience, and operational people support," they explain. "We're growing quickly, so a big part of my role involves strategic planning and change management, but I never hesitate to roll up my sleeves and get tactical. I love being at work with my team, mentoring them, and seeing them grow and learn."

What keeps them energized? Creating a culture where people feel safe to bring their whole, authentic selves to work daily.

"One of the most rewarding parts of my job is watching people grow through the organization. Seeing someone step into their potential is what drives me. MathCo has been my home for three years, and being part of its growth story feels like a privilege."

‚ÄúI was never into fitness,‚Äù Aritraa says, ‚Äúbut in 2017, a college senior casually nominated me for a marathon‚Äîand I just went for it.‚Äù She didn‚Äôt train or plan, and predictably, didn‚Äôt finish with flying colors. But what she walked away with was far more lasting‚Äîa quiet spark that soon turned into a full-blown passion. That spontaneous decision kicked off her journey into running, fitness, and the art of showing up for herself. 

Outside of work, Aritraa now finds herself lacing up her shoes more often, pushing her limits, one run at a time. ‚ÄúOver time, running made me feel happy‚Äîit gave me a high,‚Äù she shares. What began as an experiment quickly grew into a lifestyle. Her training routine includes sprint sessions, strength training, short runs, yoga for flexibility, and maintaining a healthy diet. ‚ÄúI train because I love what I do‚Äîand that keeps me going. Consistency has always been my biggest motivator.‚Äù 

Before running took over, she often played badminton with friends, especially during school and college. But over time, running took center stage. One of her proudest milestones? Clocking 10 km in 45 minutes at the Pinkathon, her fastest pace so far. ‚ÄúIt felt amazing,‚Äù she says, ‚Äúbut even more than the timing, it was about the discipline it took to get there.‚Äù 

Of course, the journey hasn‚Äôt been without its setbacks. A sprained ankle once forced her to pause and question her progress. ‚ÄúI doubted myself, of course,‚Äù she admits. ‚ÄúBut I kept reminding myself‚Äînever give up on yourself. Recovery takes time, and that‚Äôs okay.‚Äù More than physical endurance, running has built her resilience. It‚Äôs helped her stay grounded, gain clarity, and approach both life and work with more confidence. 

To fellow Mathemagicians looking to begin their fitness journey, she offers this: ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt need a gym or fancy equipment. It can be as easy as going for a walk or playing a sport you enjoy. You never know when these small things become a routine.‚Äù What started as a casual run has now become a non-negotiable part of her life‚Äîa source of joy, calm, and above all ‚Äì a daily dose of self-love. üíô 

Aritraa Bhowmik

"I did my MBA in Marketing and HR and started my career as a management trainee." says Aparna Nirmalan, Content Associate at MathCo. 
 
"During that time, I realized my strengths lay in marketing communications. I naturally gravitated towards comms and thought leadership projects, and just as I was looking to move into internal communications and talent branding, I came across the opportunity at MathCo."
 
"Even though it's only been a year here, the learning has been immense." What stands out most for Aparna is the trust and belief the team places in her.
 
"That belief has helped me believe in myself more," she shares. "I've been encouraged to take on tougher, more challenging projects, and that's pushed me to grow faster than I expected."
 
"The team works as one. There's no 'your work' or 'my work'; it's always 'our work.' If someone can't manage something, someone else steps in without hesitation."
 
"It's incredibly empowering," she adds.
 
She reflects on how exposure to diverse perspectives has reshaped her thinking‚Äîencouraging her to question, innovate, and explore bold ideas.

"People often think comms is just sending emails, but there's so much more to it. It's about message design, clarity, timing, what turns a message into something people actually connect with, especially in today's world where everyone's bombarded with information."
 
Working closely with senior leaders and being part of cross-functional projects has given her a holistic view of communication and valuable stakeholder management experience.
 
"There's also space to fail and figure things out. That freedom to experiment is a huge confidence booster. I've grown as a communicator, yes, but I've also grown as a professional who's learning to think bigger and push harder."

We recently brought together industry analysts and ecosystem partners at MathCo's Intelligence Hub in Bengaluru for a full-day event dedicated to exploring the state and future of enterprise AI transformation.

The reality is concerning: 88% of AI proof-of-concepts don't scale to enterprise-wide deployment, and only 25% of AI initiatives deliver expected ROI.

Companies invest heavily in experimentation, only to see initiatives remain isolated, fail to integrate with core processes, or struggle to demonstrate sustained value. Organizations lack a holistic framework that goes beyond individual use cases to address how AI integrates into core systems and decision-making workflows.

This is precisely the challenge that Systemic AI addresses.

Our newly launched framework, implemented through our platform NucliOS 4.0, provides a comprehensive blueprint for moving beyond PoCs to achieve genuine enterprise-wide transformation.

The response from analysts during our hands-on sessions and demonstrations was exceptionally encouraging, sparking deep discussions about how this approach solves the scaling challenges they're witnessing across industries.

Read our whitepaper to discover how this framework can serve as your solution for enterprise-wide AI transformation: LINK IN BIO!

Charlie Madison began playing piano at six, encouraged by his parents, who hoped music might offer him a gentle focus and a new way to engage with his surroundings. ‚ÄúI was always told that rhythm and melody could help my senses connect,‚Äù he shares. Those early lessons were more than just notes‚Äîthey were a lifeline, a way to find comfort and confidence.

As Charlie grew, his relationship with the piano shifted. ‚ÄúAt night, after my family fell asleep, I‚Äôd play and sing songs from my favorite singer-songwriters,‚Äù he remembers. While he practiced classical pieces during the day, those nightly sessions were different. ‚ÄúExpressing myself musically felt like a secret, a safe space away from the pressures of being the nerdy kid in a sports-focused town.‚Äù The piano became his refuge, allowing him to find his own voice at a time when he felt like an outlier.

Charlie credits the piano with teaching him the value of patience and consistent effort. ‚ÄúRepetition, repetition, repetition‚Äîthat stuck with me, whether I‚Äôm practicing a piece or debugging a tough line of code. Artistry comes from showing up and working through the details.‚Äù He‚Äôs carried that mindset into his work at MathCo, taking pride in his focus and high standards, while also learning to embrace progress over perfection. ‚ÄúIn live performances, even if you make a mistake, you keep going. Most people won‚Äôt notice, and stopping just breaks the spell.‚Äù

For Charlie, music has always been about community‚Äîmemories of high school musicals, singing telegrams with friends, and small moments of validation, like the coffee shop owner who once wrote,‚Äú It‚Äôs clear you have a lot of poetry and music in you.‚Äù Those words still mean the world.

And for anyone looking to learn piano as an adult, Charlie offers this advice: ‚ÄúIf you want to play a few favorites, have fun! But if you want to learn truly, don‚Äôt skip the basics. They‚Äôre the key to unlocking everything music has to offer.‚Äù His journey is proof that patience and a love of the process can open doors‚Äîat the piano and beyond.

#HumansofMathCo #MathCo #OwnYourIntelligence

This World Photography Day, we celebrate how a simple passion can transform the way we see the world. For Chethan, it began quietly in his backyard, photographing cats with a basic point-and-shoot camera.

But it was the visit to Kabini and the BRT Tiger Reserve that changed everything. ‚ÄúSomething about watching animals in their natural habitat just clicked. I realized this wasn‚Äôt just a hobby anymore‚Äîit was something deeper‚Äù, he reminisces.

One of his most treasured captures features a leopardess at the Bhadra Tiger Reserve. ‚ÄúShe had just woken up from a nap and was giving us all these poses. But when she yawned, that was pure magic.‚Äù Such moments make the long waits worthwhile. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve done over 100 safaris in tiger reserves and only seen tigers a couple of times. But when it happens, it‚Äôs everything.‚Äù

Wildlife photography outings are anything but predictable. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve spent three hours in a forest without seeing a single bird or animal,‚Äù he admits. ‚ÄúBut that‚Äôs part of the process. You do your research on animal behaviour and weather patterns, then you wait.‚Äù He recalls waiting for a serpent eagle to retrieve its dropped kill, a Russell‚Äôs viper snake. ‚ÄúWe never got the shot, but the experience itself was incredible.‚Äù
For those intimidated by wildlife photography, his advice is simple: ‚ÄúStart in your backyard. Photograph birds, squirrels, even insects. You don‚Äôt need to fly to the Masai Mara right away‚Äù, he quips.

The unpredictability that makes wildlife photography challenging is also what makes it beautiful. ‚ÄúWeather changes in an instant, animals don‚Äôt perform on cue, and opportunities vanish in seconds. But sometimes that ‚Äòfailed‚Äô outing leads to something even better‚Äù, he reflects.

Chethan‚Äôs journey proves that exceptional shots come from showing up consistently with patience and respect. Wildlife photography mirrors life itself‚Äîunpredictable, humbling, and ultimately rewarding.

#MathCo #MathVoice #WorldPhotographyDay

For Venkatraman G S, CFO at MathCo, every step in his journey has been intentional‚Äîtaking on challenges, driven by learning, discipline, and the belief that doing what's right matters more than convenience.

"If I had to sum up my journey in finance, it's been one of constant learning, taking on roles that required new skills, helping me set up and run multiple functions within Finance and Risk Management, building great teams, and growing as a finance professional."

From manually performing Branch Accounting to ERP rollouts to using technology for real-time reporting as CFO for fast-growing companies, Venky learned from inspiring leaders by observing what made them successful.

"As I stepped into roles I'd never done before‚Äîfront-ending client reviews, setting up business finance, or leading Enterprise Risk Management‚ÄîI realized growth doesn't come from having all the answers. It comes from asking the right questions, preparing well, and surrounding yourself with people you can learn from."

On MathCo, he says, "I see a younger, high-energy team solving high-growth problems, not just optimization ones. I'm excited to work with leadership to enable MathCo's fast-paced growth, both organic and inorganic." When leading teams, his belief is clear: "Be direct, be fair, and always offer feedback that helps people grow. Don't wait for reviews; give real-time input to build consistency and trust."

His advice to young finance professionals? "Knowing your function isn't enough. Understand your business, the customers you serve, the issues you help solve, and how your work fits the larger value chain."

He sees CFOs closely partnering with CEOs. "Technology is transforming how we work, and we must stay ahead. Finance teams must collaborate with engineers, product teams, and data scientists." Looking ahead, Venky says, I'm here to help scale the company, strengthen governance, and support leadership as we build the next phase of growth."

For him, one truth stands: "Success isn't about getting everything right, it's about getting better every day and doing what's right for the organization, not what's convenient."

#MathCo #MathCoLeadership #LeadershipJourney

"I received my undergraduate degree in English from Penn State and thought my career would be in journalism or copywriting," says Catherine Laborde, Head of Human Resources and Operations at MathCo. "It wasn't until someone I worked for said, 'Have you considered working in HR? You could turn it on its head with your people skills, conversational style, and analytical brain.' That one comment opened a door I hadn't considered."

Catherine began her HR journey nearly 15 years ago at a large specialty food store in Philadelphia, supporting a bustling catering business and shipping warehouse.

"My office was directly above the store, which gave me an up-close view of the people's experience," they recall. "I dove into hiring, problem-solving, and day-to-day support. It was HR in its most hands-on, human form".

Since then, they've built a career that spans marketing and advertising, architecture and engineering, and tech sales, always with a people-first mindset. Prior to joining MathCo, they held leadership roles and worked in a global capacity, overseeing the US, Canada, EU, UK, and APAC region, which made MathCo's international team especially appealing.

"What drew me in was the opportunity to continue working on a global scale, but with a team that truly values empathy and intelligence in equal measure.

"Now at MathCo, I oversee Recruiting, Talent, Learning & Development, the overall people experience, and operational people support," they explain. "We're growing quickly, so a big part of my role involves strategic planning and change management, but I never hesitate to roll up my sleeves and get tactical. I love being at work with my team, mentoring them, and seeing them grow and learn."

What keeps them energized? Creating a culture where people feel safe to bring their whole, authentic selves to work daily.

"One of the most rewarding parts of my job is watching people grow through the organization. Seeing someone step into their potential is what drives me. MathCo has been my home for three years, and being part of its growth story feels like a privilege."

‚ÄúI was never into fitness,‚Äù Aritraa says, ‚Äúbut in 2017, a college senior casually nominated me for a marathon‚Äîand I just went for it.‚Äù She didn‚Äôt train or plan, and predictably, didn‚Äôt finish with flying colors. But what she walked away with was far more lasting‚Äîa quiet spark that soon turned into a full-blown passion. That spontaneous decision kicked off her journey into running, fitness, and the art of showing up for herself.

Outside of work, Aritraa now finds herself lacing up her shoes more often, pushing her limits, one run at a time. ‚ÄúOver time, running made me feel happy‚Äîit gave me a high,‚Äù she shares. What began as an experiment quickly grew into a lifestyle. Her training routine includes sprint sessions, strength training, short runs, yoga for flexibility, and maintaining a healthy diet. ‚ÄúI train because I love what I do‚Äîand that keeps me going. Consistency has always been my biggest motivator.‚Äù

Before running took over, she often played badminton with friends, especially during school and college. But over time, running took center stage. One of her proudest milestones? Clocking 10 km in 45 minutes at the Pinkathon, her fastest pace so far. ‚ÄúIt felt amazing,‚Äù she says, ‚Äúbut even more than the timing, it was about the discipline it took to get there.‚Äù

Of course, the journey hasn‚Äôt been without its setbacks. A sprained ankle once forced her to pause and question her progress. ‚ÄúI doubted myself, of course,‚Äù she admits. ‚ÄúBut I kept reminding myself‚Äînever give up on yourself. Recovery takes time, and that‚Äôs okay.‚Äù More than physical endurance, running has built her resilience. It‚Äôs helped her stay grounded, gain clarity, and approach both life and work with more confidence.

To fellow Mathemagicians looking to begin their fitness journey, she offers this: ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt need a gym or fancy equipment. It can be as easy as going for a walk or playing a sport you enjoy. You never know when these small things become a routine.‚Äù What started as a casual run has now become a non-negotiable part of her life‚Äîa source of joy, calm, and above all ‚Äì a daily dose of self-love. üíô

"I did my MBA in Marketing and HR and started my career as a management trainee." says Aparna Nirmalan, Content Associate at MathCo. 
 
"During that time, I realized my strengths lay in marketing communications. I naturally gravitated towards comms and thought leadership projects, and just as I was looking to move into internal communications and talent branding, I came across the opportunity at MathCo."
 
"Even though it's only been a year here, the learning has been immense." What stands out most for Aparna is the trust and belief the team places in her.
 
"That belief has helped me believe in myself more," she shares. "I've been encouraged to take on tougher, more challenging projects, and that's pushed me to grow faster than I expected."
 
"The team works as one. There's no 'your work' or 'my work'; it's always 'our work.' If someone can't manage something, someone else steps in without hesitation."
 
"It's incredibly empowering," she adds.
 She reflects on how exposure to diverse perspectives has reshaped her thinking‚Äîencouraging her to question, innovate, and explore bold ideas.

"People often think comms is just sending emails, but there's so much more to it. It's about message design, clarity, timing, what turns a message into something people actually connect with, especially in today's world where everyone's bombarded with information."
 
Working closely with senior leaders and being part of cross-functional projects has given her a holistic view of communication and valuable stakeholder management experience.
 
"There's also space to fail and figure things out. That freedom to experiment is a huge confidence booster. I've grown as a communicator, yes, but I've also grown as a professional who's learning to think bigger and push harder."

#MathCo #MathVoice

üîµ News from hashtag#SnowflakeSummit 2025 üîµ

We are expanding our collaboration with Snowflake to help enterprises unlock greater value from their data and accelerate AI-driven innovation.

MathCo is proud to launch the MathCo Center of Excellence (CoE) for Snowflake, a focused initiative aimed at helping Fortune 500 and Global 2000 companies scale their AI and ML ambitions faster and smarter.

Our CoE will bring together deep domain expertise, a Snowflake-certified workforce, and 100+ real-world use cases across Retail, CPG, Life Sciences, and Healthcare, delivering solutions that drive strategic decisions and measurable impact.

What makes this partnership powerful?
- A shared mission to make every organization truly data-driven

- A stronger focus on business-ready, custom solutions

When the pandemic brought the world to a standstill in 2020, Radhika B. found an unexpected sanctuary in the quiet world of plants. What began as a way to pass the time soon became a lifeline, filling her home with greenery and her days with purpose. Initially drawn to gardening through YouTube videos, Radhika discovered more than just a hobby-she found a passion that taught her patience and resilience. 
 
Her approach to gardening is intuitive and compassionate. She believes each plant has a unique personality and needs‚Äîsome thrive under bright sunlight, others demand shade. She groups plants accordingly and practices ‚Äúintentional neglect‚Äù‚Äîresisting the urge to overwater because the soil appears dry. Surprisingly, the most challenging plants for her have been succulents. Though often labeled 'low maintenance,' she found them deceptively tricky, requiring the perfect balance of well-draining soil, sunlight, and minimal watering. 
 
Despite space constraints, Radhika has created a thriving indoor oasis in her home. Her collection includes Snake Plants, Monsteras, Palms, and Ficus, while her balcony doubles as a mini vegetable garden with chilies, tomatoes, fenugreek, and mint. She experiments with unusual plants, including Mother of Thousands, a fascinating species that grows baby plantlets along its leaf edges. Sustainability is vital in her gardening philosophy‚Äîshe repurposes containers, composts kitchen waste, and has a special "green second chance" jar for failed plant cuttings. 
 
For Radhika, gardening is more than just growing plants‚Äîit's about slowing down and embracing nature's rhythm. "In a world obsessed with speed, gardening slows you down. It teaches you that real, lasting growth takes time, care, and a bit of faith,‚Äù she reflects. As she looks to the future, she hopes to deepen her understanding of soil composition, explore vertical gardening, and venture into hydroponics. For aspiring gardeners, her advice is simple yet powerful: start small. "Borrow a cutting, find a sunny windowsill, and just begin. Failure is part of the journey, but plants are more forgiving than people think," she shares.  For extra guidance, she recommends YouTube channels like "Garden Up," which played a significant role in shaping her green thumb. With every new leaf and unexpected bud, Radhika continues cultivating not just plants but also patience, joy, and a deep connection with nature.

It's World Art Day‚Äîa reminder to pause and celebrate the creativity that enriches our everyday lives. At MathCo, this creativity takes many forms, including in the thoughtful sketches of Design Associate Nikhil, whose artistic journey reveals how art can become both a personal sanctuary and a powerful form of self-expression.

Nikhil's affinity for art began during his school days as a simple pastime. "I have been sketching since my school days. What once started as a hobby eventually grew to be a form of therapy," he shares. Self-taught and driven by curiosity, Nikhil started with simple pictures and gradually progressed to exploring light, shadow, and emotion.

Nikhil's work thrives in the balance between structure and freedom. "With portraits, I like showing emotions and small details in people's faces. It feels special," he explains. "Abstract is also fun‚Äîthere are no rules, just whatever I feel in the moment." His creative process is largely intuitive. "Sometimes I just start drawing with no plan, and slowly, an idea forms in my head. I like creating things that don't exist in real life‚Äîbut still feel like they could." Imagination leads the way, but emotions and real-life experiences shape what eventually takes form on paper.

Like many artists, he's learned to navigate the natural ebbs and flows of creativity. When inspiration wanes, he turns to rest, music, or nature‚Äîallowing his creative spark to return organically. Over time, patience has become integral to his process, especially when experimenting with detailed dot work using black pens. "It takes time, but I enjoy the detail and patience it needs."

Among his works, one sketch stands out‚Äîa warrior woman adorned with feathers, poised with a bow. "That sketch reminded me of the fighter in me; it wasn't planned‚Äîit just came out of how I was feeling," he reflects. For Nikhil, art is a quiet conversation‚Äîbetween thought, feeling, and imagination. This World Art Day, we celebrate that voice and art's power to connect us with ourselves and each other.

#MathCo #HumansofMathCo #WorldArtDay

This√¢‚Ç¨¬ØWomen's History Month, we're celebrating women who are shaping a better future for themselves and the world. Sangeetha Kannan, Project Manager at MathCo,√¢‚Ç¨¬Øis one such changemaker. Through small yet powerful choices, she champions sustainable living, proving that everyday actions can make a lasting impact.
 
"The world doesn't need a few people doing zero waste perfectly.√¢‚Ç¨¬ØWhat it needs is√¢‚Ç¨¬Ømillions of people doing zero waste imperfectly," says Sangeetha Kannan.
 
Sangeetha is a staunch believer in this. She shares,√¢‚Ç¨¬Ø"I set out trying to find small ways in which I could contribute to the betterment of the world."√¢‚Ç¨¬ØHer journey toward sustainability proves that even the√¢‚Ç¨¬Øsimplest√¢‚Ç¨¬Øchanges can create a ripple effect.
 
One of her√¢‚Ç¨¬Øeasiest√¢‚Ç¨¬Øand most impactful shifts was√¢‚Ç¨¬Ørefusing single-use items.√¢‚Ç¨¬Ø"Pledge to spend a few extra minutes every day, and you'll be well on your way to cutting down on single-use consumption,"√¢‚Ç¨¬Øshe says. Waste segregation and composting wet waste at home have also been game changers√¢‚Ç¨‚Äùsmall efforts that lead to√¢‚Ç¨¬Øsignificant environmental impact.
 
Sangeetha has incorporated several√¢‚Ç¨¬Øeco-friendly alternatives√¢‚Ç¨¬Øinto her daily routine:

√¢≈ì‚Äù√¢‚Ç¨¬ØCoconut coir & wood-based cleaning brushes
√¢≈ì‚Äù√¢‚Ç¨¬ØHomemade bio enzyme cleaner√¢‚Ç¨¬Ø(citrus peels + jaggery + water in a 10:3:1 ratio)
√¢≈ì‚Äù√¢‚Ç¨¬ØNatural tooth powder√¢‚Ç¨¬Øin a glass jar instead of plastic toothpaste tubes
√¢≈ì‚Äù√¢‚Ç¨¬ØBamboo toothbrushes√¢‚Ç¨¬Øinstead of plastic ones√¢‚Ç¨¬Ø(Every toothbrush you've ever used still exists somewhere!)
√¢≈ì‚Äù√¢‚Ç¨¬ØMenstrual cups√¢‚Ç¨¬Øinstead of disposable sanitary napkins
√¢≈ì‚Äù√¢‚Ç¨¬ØKajal in a tin box, used with a wooden applicator
√¢≈ì‚Äù√¢‚Ç¨¬ØWooden combs (neem/bamboo)√¢‚Ç¨¬Øinstead of plastic combs
√¢≈ì‚Äù√¢‚Ç¨¬ØReed diffusers with essential oils√¢‚Ç¨¬Øinstead of artificial air fresheners
 
She left us with some easy steps to reduce single-use items:

√¢≈ì‚ÄùCarry a water bottle√¢‚Ç¨¬Ø√¢‚Ç¨‚Äú Refilling is an easy, sustainable choice, whether it's a short outing or a long trip.
√¢≈ì‚ÄùUse a handkerchief√¢‚Ç¨¬Ø√¢‚Ç¨‚Äú The next generation needs trees more than we need disposable tissues.
√¢≈ì‚ÄùKeep cloth bags handy√¢‚Ç¨¬Ø√¢‚Ç¨‚Äú Store extras in your vehicle and always carry a few smaller ones.
√¢≈ì‚ÄùPack food containers & reusable cutlery√¢‚Ç¨¬Ø√¢‚Ç¨‚Äú A small step to avoid unnecessary packaging waste.
√¢≈ì‚ÄùOpt for dining out instead of ordering in√¢‚Ç¨¬Ø√¢‚Ç¨‚Äú Enjoy your meal while cutting down on plastic packaging.
 
Sangeetha's approach is simple:√¢‚Ç¨¬Øprogress over perfection.√¢‚Ç¨¬ØLet's take inspiration from her journey and commit to making√¢‚Ç¨¬Øsustainable choices, one habit at a time.
 
#MathCo #SustainabilityChampion #StrongerWithHer #WomensHistoryMonth #WomenAtMathCo

Engineers Week Special featuring Tapas Das, Data Architect at MathCo!
 
At MathCo, our engineers don't just build systems√¢‚Ç¨‚Äùthey solve complex problems, innovate with cutting-edge tech, and push the boundaries of data and AI.
 
We sat down with√Ç¬†Tapas√Ç¬†to talk about his journey, what keeps him inspired, and his top book and game recommendations!
 
1. How did you get into engineering? Was it always the plan?
 
I got into engineering because I've always been fascinated by problem-solving and building scalable systems. Early on, I was drawn to how technology could transform raw data into meaningful insights, and that naturally led me into the world of data architecture.
 
Was it always the plan? Not exactly. While I had a strong inclination towards technology, my specific path into data engineering and architecture evolved over time. Initially, I was more focused on software development, but as I worked with large datasets and complex system designs, I realized that data engineering was where my strengths and interests aligned.
 
2. What made you choose MathCo?
 
I chose MathCo because it aligns with my passion for building scalable, high-performance data architectures and multi-cloud platforms while also providing opportunities to shape MLOps and LLMOps frameworks.
 
A few key reasons stood out are "Focus on Data & AI", "culture of innovation and technical ownership", "A Great Team & Vision".
 
3. How do you manage to game, read, and watch shows?
 
It's all about balance and priorities! Gaming is my go-to for unwinding, especially after a long workday. Currently I'm playing a story-driven game, so I plan it like a mini-series√¢‚Ç¨‚Äùplay for an hour or two and continue later.
 
I also keep my Kindle handy to be able to read on the go. Whenever I can squeeze in 20-30 minutes.
 
6. What's your current read? Looking for book recommendations!
 
Right now, I'm reading The Black Dahlia by James Ellroy, and it's keeping me hooked with its perfect mix of suspense, eerie atmosphere, and mind-bending twists. But I'd also recommend these 5 books for different moods and genres.
 
For a slow-burn psychological thriller, The Silent Patient by Alex Michaelides
For sci-fi and mind-bending twists, Dark Matter by Blake Crouch
For dark humor and absurdity, A Dirty Job by Christopher Moore
For layered mysteries, Magpie Murders by Anthony Horowitz
 
7. What's the best thing about being part of the MathCo engineering team?
 
A perfect blend of innovation, collaboration, and technical challenges. There's always an opportunity to experiment with the latest tools in data engineering, ML engineering, and AI-driven optimizations. The focus isn't just on delivering code, it's on building future-proof systems that drive business outcomes. Being part of the MathCo engineering team means working with brilliant minds, cutting-edge tech, and solving real-world challenges√¢‚Ç¨‚Äùall while having the freedom to innovate, learn, and make a difference.

AI is reshaping the HR landscape.
 
AI's transformative power is undeniable, but its impact on HR is particularly game-changing. Why?
 
Daniil Mosin, Principal, MathCo, explains how HR thrives on data-driven insights to manage people, culture, and growth.
 
As organizations shift from descriptive to predictive and prescriptive analytics, HR is leveraging AI to:

√¢≈ì‚Äù Enhance decision-making
√¢≈ì‚Äù Optimize operations
√¢≈ì‚Äù Personalize employee experiences
 
Heading into 2025, here are the top 5 AI trends shaping HR:
 
√¢≈ì‚Ä¶ Generative AI in talent acquisition: AI models are increasingly used to screen candidates, predict top performers and "early flight" risks, and streamline operational processes, like scheduling interviews.

Leading players see a 4x improvement in candidate conversion and a 25% reduction in time to interview via the adoption of AI tools.
 
√¢≈ì‚Ä¶ Predictive workforce planning: Individual-level attrition prediction and skill-based workforce demand forecasting become critical instruments of workforce planning alongside scenario modeling (e.g., hybrid vs. in-person).

For example, some of the early adopters see a 4% reduction in attrition levels via individual-level prediction and a deeper understanding of influencing factors.
 
√¢≈ì‚Ä¶ The proliferation of employee wellness and engagement tools: - Personalization of employee experience: AI enables hyper-personalized learning and development plans based on employee performance and individual preferences, which become ever more relevant as the technology pace accelerates.

Employee upskilling and reskilling become more frequent needs, and virtual assistants provide instant coaching and answers to HR-related queries. Additionally, advanced analytics opens opportunities to design better benefits programs based on utilization statistics and employee data.
 
√¢≈ì‚Ä¶ Organizational modeling and optimization enabled by advanced analytics: Companies leverage advanced analytics to design optimal organizational structures, simulate workforce scenarios, identify efficiency bottlenecks, and streamline operating models.

#MathCo #AITrends #AITrendsinHR #HumanResources #OwnYourIntelligence

Supply chains are subject to political disputes, pandemics, and jammed ports that can grind everything to a halt. Traditional predictive analytics are too sluggish to keep pace with the chaos. 

Next Best Action (NBA) is a prescriptive analytics tool that prescribes actions that can be taken by running real-time simulations to dodge disruptions before they blow up.
 
NBA helps with cost cuts, faster decisions, and offers resilience to supply chain management. But it needs sharp tech, clean data, and a little trust in AI to make it work.

A standard large book has certain continuous pages missing (e.g., pages 19 to 24 are missing).

√¢≈ì‚Ä¶ Computing Engine - executes the agents' assigned tasks in real-time.
√¢≈ì‚Ä¶ Batch Processing System - handles tasks that involve non-real-time data.
√¢≈ì‚Ä¶ Studio Interface - allows users to manage agents, define tasks, and oversee system operations interactively.

Our system used multi-agent coordination, improving resilience, reducing latency and increasing capability in various multi-industry use cases. For Priya, balancing business growth with trust, cultivating a culture of security-conscious teams worldwide, and rigorously vetting third-party partners are all part of the playbook. Her leadership style focuses on creating systems that are both elegantly secure and empowering, enabling people to innovate without fear.

On August 16, Fractal Ukraine team took part in a full-day workshop on First aid (Intensive Bleed) and Behavior with Explosives, conducted by the Prytula Foundation.

The session combined hands-on practical exercises with theory, equipping Fractalites with essential skills such as stopping intensive bleeding, applying tourniquets, and giving first aid. In addition, the team learned about the critical do‚Äôs and don'ts around explosive objects, ensuring awareness and preparedness in real-life scenarios.

It was a day of valuable knowledge, practical training, and teamwork - empowering us to act responsibly and effectively in emergency situations.

The biggest disruption today, in CPG and Retail, isn‚Äôt a new food or beauty product; it‚Äôs ChatGPT. It‚Äôs changing how people shop.

For Mrunali, this shift captures the excitement of leading in an industry where AI is reshaping the path to purchase. Drawing from her early training in consumer insights, she has built a philosophy centered on one truth: every successful solution must start and end with people.

As Chief Practice Officer at Fractal, Mrunali has championed this approach by integrating AI and engineering into business solutions while keeping business decision-makers at the center. Guided by client centricity, trust, and a culture of learning, she thrives on solving complex problems. Her leadership mantra is simple yet bold: do the right thing, not just the easy thing; take risks but provide a safety net for your team; and lead with authenticity, in work and in life.

Her message for CPG and Retail companies is clear: agility wins!

Those who adopt AI to understand and relate to consumers faster than ever before will own the marketplace.

Nearly two decades ago, Devendra, a young consultant, learned a lesson that would change everything: "The model doesn‚Äôt matter if it doesn‚Äôt impact decisions." The goal wasn‚Äôt to build better models, it was to drive better decisions.

It wasn't about creating the perfect algorithm. It was about understanding and empowering the human on the other side of the screen to make a better choice.

His journey spanned continents. Mumbai taught resilience and innovation under pressure. Singapore and UK revealed how diverse cultures tackle problems uniquely. In the US, Devendra experienced the swift advancement of AI up close, working alongside some of the brightest minds in the industry.

Three moments defined his transformation:

ùêÖùê¢ùê´ùê¨ùê≠, when technical perfection gave way to business impact. The realization that perfect model metrics mean nothing if it doesn't help drive a better decision.

ùêíùêûùêúùê®ùêßùêù, being the smartest person in the room became less rewarding than empowering others. Seeing a team member ace a critical presentation became more rewarding than any personal win.

In a career spanning over two decades, Sagar Shah has played a pivotal role in driving digital transformation at over 25 Fortune 100 companies, establishing a proud legacy of achievements. He has led many transformative initiatives that include leading AI programs in marketing and sales analytics, Responsible AI projects, scaling next best action, vaccine hesitancy, and patient analytics, driving eCommerce, DTC, and digital initiatives, establishing Fortune 100 Centers of Excellence, and more.
 
Sagar is rooted in a philosophy likening consultants to doctors addressing patients' concerns; his approach emphasizes meticulous investigation, experimentation, and continual refinement. This guiding ethos, complemented by an unwavering dedication to ongoing learning and adaptability, has charted a diverse career trajectory - from chemical engineering and biochemistry research to venturing into digital transformations for consumer goods companies to behavioral science and machine learning in Pharma companies and beyond.
 
Sagar's core traits of curiosity, creativity, and humility serve as his guiding leadership principles, fostering an environment of proactive engagement, transparency, and professional development. Drawing inspiration from generational wisdom, he prioritizes integrity, hard work, and fearlessness in navigating professional and personal challenges.
 
Amidst the evolving landscape of the pharma industry driven by digital disruption, Sagar champions user-centric methodologies, agile prototyping, and the integration of AI as a collaborative force, all aimed at advancing healthcare outcomes for the betterment of society.

Here‚Äôs Shubham's throwback on the unique holiday gift he gifted his wife!
‚ÄúAs we welcomed our baby girl into the world, I wanted to gift my wife something that truly reflected the depth of my gratitude. That‚Äôs when I chose a pair of sustainable, lab-grown diamond earrings.

As I held our daughter in my arms, I realized no material gift could ever fully express what I felt. But I wanted to try, by choosing something intentional. Something that carried meaning.

The diamond represents the timeless strength and beauty of our love, while also aligning with my values of sustainability and purpose.

In a world where values shine as brightly as style, lab-grown diamonds are more than just stunning; they‚Äôre meaningful. Ethically created, planet-friendly, and every bit as radiant as their mined counterparts. These gems are a tribute to the modern woman: confident, conscious, and uncompromising.

When my wife opened the box, her eyes sparkled, not just with joy, but with recognition. It was a reflection of who we are and the future we‚Äôre building for our daughter, rooted in mindful choices and lasting love.

For us, it became something even more:
A quiet vow.
A promise to cherish the present, honor the future, and let our values lead the way.

A bit of context:
At Fractal, we do things a little differently. Like most great companies, we love celebrating the end of an amazing year and recognizing the incredible work everyone does. This time, we got something extra special ‚Äì the freedom to choose our own annual holiday gift.

Some of us chose gifts for ourselves, some for our loved ones. Others saw it as a chance to support local artisans or make a difference. It wasn't just about getting a gift but about making a difference.

Stay tuned for more such stories.

#HolidayGifts #Culture

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a saying, ‚ÄòIf you never enter the water, you‚Äôll never learn how to swim.‚Äô And from a very young age, I‚Äôve always stepped into uncharted waters & figured my way through.

At 21, I moved abroad to fulfill my ‚Äòbig American dream‚Äô, complete my master‚Äôs & earn in dollars. But the world there was entirely different - new people, different cultures. I had to manage it all by myself. But the only thing that kept me going was video calls with my parents.

But as my assignments piled up, even those calls were reduced. Mom would always ask, ‚ÄòWhen are you coming home?‚Äô I had no answer. I wanted to return home only after achieving something. So when I got a job as an Analyst, I immersed myself in learning everything. For the next few years, everything took a backseat.

During this time, I was introduced to Fractal; they were our AI partners. From the start, I was in awe of their work & people.

But right when I was thinking of making changes to my professional life, Dad called, ‚ÄòYour mom had a heart attack.‚Äô I thought, ‚ÄòWhat was the point of this if I couldn‚Äôt be there for Mom?‚Äô So I decided to move back to India. But the question remained, what about my job?

At that time, the only company I could think of was Fractal. I approached Srikanth, Fractal‚Äôs co-founder & he just said, ‚ÄòWe would love to have you.‚Äô

And so, in 2018, I moved back to India. And that‚Äôs when I realized what I was truly missing - celebrating birthdays together, my sons understanding the true meaning of family & work has never felt more satisfying.

Since joining Fractal, I‚Äôve had countless opportunities to grow. In fact, during Covid, I even got the opportunity to lead a task force to help the government manage health service responses. I could make a real difference. So I worked 18 hours a day, took 2 AM calls & even worked while I was down with Covid, to deliver on time. And I did. Within 24 hours, we built a platform that enabled govt of Karnataka to manage Covid operations efficiently.

And through it all, I‚Äôve realized that success isn‚Äôt just about the milestones you reach - it‚Äôs about the people who stand by you & the memories you create together.‚Äù

For Gen Z, work isn‚Äôt just about salary or titles - it‚Äôs about aesthetic. From Halloween cupcakes to Instagram-worthy office setups, today‚Äôs young professionals are drawn to companies that bring good vibes and postable moments.

In this fun and honest chat- Abhishek, Sheetal and Papiya reveal how workplace culture, themed events, and shareable perks influence where they want to work.

Because let‚Äôs be real - if it‚Äôs not on the ‚Äògram, did it even happen?

The Moment It Clicked: Fractal's True Scale

Ever wonder about the true impact of your work?

For Natwar, it hit during a Client Advisory Board. When clients spoke about how Fractal empowers them personally and professionally. That's when it clicked. We're not just advising, we're fundamentally changing lives and businesses by powering better decisions.

It feels good to do good

#ClientImpact #DecisionMaking #Fractal #Fractal25 #CAB

When Fractal offered us the freedom to choose our own holiday gift this year, Khushboo saw an opportunity to give back. She chose to support Maru Ghar, a home for elderly citizens. Here's her story:

‚ÄúI hadn‚Äôt planned anything for the holidays, but when Fractal decided to let us choose the holiday gift of our choice, something nudged me to do more. I decided to visit Maru Ghar, home to 130+ elderly residents who, despite always greeting visitors with warm smiles, often feel forgotten by society and their families.

What struck me immediately was the incredible warmth of the place. Despite everything they've endured, the residents create a joyful family atmosphere, sharing stories and laughing together over meals.

Talking to the wonderful people who looked after the young at heart, I was deeply moved. They spoke with so much love for the residents as if caring for their own family. Their humble, unwavering commitment was truly inspiring.

What makes Maru Ghar so special isn‚Äôt just the care they provide, but the sense of belonging they provide for those who‚Äôve been left behind. It‚Äôs a place where every bit of support is transformed into warmth, respect, and community.

A li‚Äôl bit of context:

At Fractal, much like most good companies, we celebrated the end of another amazing year and the incredible work everyone accomplishes through an annual holiday gift.

This time around, all of us got to choose our own annual holiday gift. This gave us the freedom to choose it however we wanted. Some chose to gift themselves or even their loved ones, some to support local artisans, and some to use this as an opportunity to make a difference.

Stay tuned for more such stories.

Why is #Fractal a disruptor? Can artificial intelligence truly defeat humans in just three-five years?

Co-founder & Group CEO Srikanth Velamakanni shares his story and ideas with Tamanna Inamdar.

Tune in to 'The Disruptors' at 6pm on May 23.

You know that feeling when the world throws a curveball and somehow someone turns it into an opportunity? That's exactly what happened in March 2020.

James Davies took on the challenge of building something new in a world that had hit a standstill. But instead of waiting for clarity, he created it through conversations, curiosity, and a sharp focus on what really matters: client outcomes. Here‚Äôs what that looked like in action:

üî∏ Insurance relies heavily on data, but it often lacks the personal touch needed to truly meet an individual's needs. When his team, taught AI to scan aerial photos after hurricanes, they weren't just being tech-savvy; they were ensuring that real people received help before they even had to ask.
üî∏ His team's AI solution helped underwriters review more opportunities despite being buried in paperwork. Not because the technology was flashy, but because someone took the time to understand what people actually needed.

The magic isn't in complicated algorithms, it's in those casual "hey, what if we tried this?" conversations that happen between meetings. It's about putting clients first and thinking big while moving quickly.

"Comparison is the thief of joy," James often says. Instead of measuring yourself against others, why not pour that energy into making the most of what's right in front of you?

That's the approach that's changing how insurance works, making it less about paperwork and more about being there when it matters most.

What would you do if you were gifted a small sum - enough for a five-star meal or a little shopping spree? For Nitika Goel, it became an opportunity to contribute to something much larger - Vedic Kanya High School in Gurgaon, an institution that has been quietly changing lives by educating girls from underprivileged communities since 1959. Here‚Äôs her special holiday story:

‚ÄúI've been inspired by Vedic Kanya High School for years now. Many girls have to walk long distances through all kinds of weather just to get to class ‚Äì talk about dedication! When Fractal gave us the freedom to pick our holiday gifts this year, it just clicked ‚Äì those sweaters and shoes we take for granted could make a big difference in their journey to a better future.

What really gets me about Vedic Kanya isn't just what they do, but how they've kept at it for over 60 years, believing in these girls when most didn't. They're not just educating but building future leaders in communities where education for girls isn't always valued.

Big thanks to Fractal for letting us choose gifts that matter to us. It's pretty cool seeing how a school like Vedic Kanya keeps making waves of change decade after decade.‚Äù

A li'l bit of context:

At Fractal, much like most good companies, we celebrated the end of another amazing year, and the incredible work everyone accomplishes through an annual holiday gift.

This time around, all of us got to choose our own annual holiday gift. This gave us the freedom to choose it however we wanted. Some chose to gift themselves or even their loved ones, some to support local artisans, and some to use this as an opportunity to make a difference.

I‚Äôm truly honored to share that Fractal has been selected by the Government of India under the hashtag#IndiaAI Mission to build the nation‚Äôs first Large Reasoning Model (LRM).

This is not a project - it is a national mission to place India at the forefront of AI innovation. 

As part of this initiative, Fractal will:
1. Build sovereign reasoning models from small to large scale (2B ‚Üí 70B parameters).
2. Develop specialized medical reasoning models to advance healthcare.
3. Create a global benchmark in reasoning based on India‚Äôs toughest exams (JEE, NEET, Olympiads, CAT, GATE).
4. Ground the models in India‚Äôs linguistic and cultural context, ensuring fairness, neutrality, and sovereignty.

This is a proud moment not just for Fractal, but for India‚Äôs AI ecosystem. By investing in reasoning capabilities, India can lead the world in building AI that is not only powerful, but also trustworthy, ethical, and inclusive.

A heartfelt thanks to the hashtag#IndiaAI Mission for their trust, and to the brilliant AI reserach team at Fractal under Suraj's leadership whose dedication and research excellence have brought us here.

At Fractal's ùêçùêûùê∞ ùêòùê®ùê´ùê§ ùêÑùê±ùêûùêúùêÆùê≠ùê¢ùêØùêû ùêíùêÆùê¶ùê¶ùê¢ùê≠ on September 18, conversations dove into the real work of building AI-first enterprises.

Pranay Agrawal kicked off the event with an inspiring keynote on the 'Evolution of Intelligence' and why many Fortune 500 companies struggle to turn AI enthusiasm into measurable enterprise performance. He examined how organizations can better leverage AI to re-skill their workforce, drive innovation, and design inclusive systems that benefit everyone.

In the first fireside chat, Shashi Reddy and Mrunali Majmudar unpacked what it truly means to be an AI-ready organization. It‚Äôs not just about having the right tools, it‚Äôs about aligning data strategy, governance, and security with a culture that‚Äôs open to transformation. From balancing quick wins with long-term bets to building trust in AI-driven decisions, they emphasized that people and processes matter just as much as platforms.

Kevin McCurdy joined Dylan Dias to discuss the infrastructure needed to move AI from pilot to production. The session explored how enterprise-grade AI demands more than compute, calls for hybrid cloud-edge models, and thoughtful orchestration. Cost-performance optimization, scalability, and governance are now inseparable from AI success, and enterprises that get this right will lead the next wave of transformation.

The final session, featuring Scott Engle and Himanshu Nautiyal, spotlighted the rise of autonomous AI agents. These aren‚Äôt just tools to automate tasks, they‚Äôre evolving into intelligent collaborators capable of driving enterprise outcomes. Scaling them requires more than tech readiness. It demands new operating models, trust frameworks, and a willingness to reimagine workflows from the ground up.

Together, these conversations painted a picture of where enterprise AI is heading and what it takes to lead the way. 

We can‚Äôt wait for the next summit!
